choices.text: Lower limb long bones heal faster than other bones
Fracture in children heal faster than in adults
Oblique and spiral fractures heal faster than transverse fractures

questions.text: About fracture healing, all are true, except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lower limb long bones heal faster than other bones
Ref.:Read the text below
Sol :
•	Type of fracture : Transverse fractures unite slowly compared to oblique or spiral fractures. 
•	Type of bone : Fracture at the cancellous ends of bone unites better than those in the mid shaft of long bones where cancellous bone is minimal. 
•	General Causes : 
•	Fractures in children unite very rapidly whereas delayed union is common in the aged.

questions.text: Sun-ray appearance in osteosarcoma is due to –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A newborn child presents with inverted foot and the dorsum of the foot can not touch the anterior tibia. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CTEV 
Ref: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 11thed.
Sol:
CONGENITAL CLUBFOOT (TALIPES EQUINOVARUS)
•	The three basic components of clubfoot are equinus, varus, and adduction deformities. 
•	The deformity varies in severity, however; the entire foot may be in an equinus and varus position with the forefoot adducted and a cavus deformity present, or the condition may be much less severe, with the foot being in only a mild equinus and varusposition .
•	 Clubfoot is accompanied by internal tibial torsion. The ankle, midtarsal, and subtalar joints all are involved in the pathological process.
•	The heel appears to be in varus because the calcaneus rotates through the talocalcaneal joint in a coronal plane and horizontally. 
•	The talonavicular joint is in an extreme position of inversion as the navicular moves around the head of the talus. The cuboid is displaced medially on the calcaneus
•	The order of correction by serial manipulation and casting should be as follows: first, correction of forefoot adduction; next, correction of heel varus; and finally, correction of hindfootequinus. 
•	Correction should be pursued in this order so that a rocker-bottom deformity would be prevented by dorsiflexing the foot through the hindfoot rather than the midfoot.

questions.text: Which of the following option matches the image above ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All of the following ae true about the following image except :

choices.text: It is an Autosomal Dominant disorder
It is the most common cause of Disproportionate dwarfism
Maximum height achieved is usually 4 feet
It’s a defect in intramembranous ossification

questions.text: which of the following statement is not true about the condition shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A. It is an Autosomal Dominant disorder: This statement is True. Achondroplasia is indeed inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning a single copy of the mutated gene (FGFR3) is sufficient to cause the condition.

B. It is the most common cause of Disproportionate dwarfism: This statement is True. Achondroplasia is the most frequent cause of disproportionate short stature, where the limbs are significantly shorter than the trunk.

C. Maximum height achieved is usually 4 feet: This statement is True. The average adult height for individuals with achondroplasia is typically around 131 cm (4 feet 3 inches) for males and 124 cm (4 feet 1 inch) for females, making "usually 4 feet" a reasonable approximation.

D. It’s a defect in intramembranous ossification: This statement is False. Achondroplasia is a defect in endochondral ossification, which is the process by which most bones, especially long bones, develop from cartilage templates. Intramembranous ossification is the process by which flat bones (like those of the skull and clavicle) develop directly from mesenchymal tissue without a cartilage intermediate.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fracture shown in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURES
•	These are among the commonest fractures in children. 
•	The distal fragment may be displaced either posteriorly or anteriorly.

MECHANISM OF INJURY:
•	Posterior angulation or displacement (95 per cent of all cases) suggests a hyperextension injury, usually due to a fall on the outstretched hand. 
•	The humerus breaks just above the condyles. 
•	The distal fragment is pushed backwards and (because the forearm is usually in pronation) twisted inwards. 
•	The jagged end of the proximal fragment pokes into the soft tissues anteriorly sometimes injuring the brachial artery or median nerve.
•	Anterior displacement is rare (option ‘1’); it is thought to be due to direct violence (e.g. a fall on the point of the elbow) with the joint in flexion.

CLINICAL FEATURES:
•	Following a fall, the child is in pain and the elbow is swollen; with a posteriorly displaced fracture the S-deformity of the elbow is usually obvious and the bony landmarks are abnormal. 
•	It is essential to feel the pulse and check the capillary return; passive extension
•	of the flexor muscles should be pain-free. 
•	The wrist and the hand should be examined for evidence of nerve injury.
•	The fracture is seen most clearly in the lateral view. 
•	In an undisplaced fracture the ‘fat pad sign’ should raise suspicions: there is a triangular lucency in front of the distal humerus, due to the fat pad being pushed forwards by a haematoma.
•	The radial nerve, median nerve (particularly the anterior interosseous branch) or the ulnar nerve may be injured. 
•	Fortunately loss of function is usually temporary and recovery can be expected in 3 to 4 months (option ‘3’). 
•	If there is no recovery the nerve should be explored. 
•	However, if a nerve, documented as intact prior to manipulation, is then found to have failed after manipulation, then entrapment in the fracture is suspected and immediate exploration should be arranged.

COMPLICATIONS:
•	Malunion is common. 
•	However, backward or sideways shifts are gradually smoothed out by modelling during growth and they seldom give rise to visible deformity of the elbow. 
•	Forward or backward tilt may limit flexion or extension, but consequent disability is slight.
•	Weakness of elbow extension is commonly observed (option ‘4’). 
•	Uncorrected sideways tilt (angulation) and rotation are much more important and may lead to varus (or rarely valgus) deformity of the elbow (option ‘2’); this is permanent and will not improve with growth (gun-stock deformity). 
•	The fracture is extra-physeal and so physeal damage should not be blamed for the deformity; usually it is faulty reduction which is responsible. 
•	Cubitus varus is disfiguring and cubitus valgus may cause late ulnar palsy. 
•	If deformity is marked, it will need correction by supracondylar osteotomy usually once the child approaches skeletal maturity.

questions.text: Steps in the operative correction of congenital talipes equinovarus include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Release of peroneus brevis from its insertion
•	The crucial component in CTEV is subluxation of the talonavicular joint. The soft tissues on the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped and shorter than normal. 
•	Aim of treatment is to set the tarsal bones in normal relationship to one another and to relieve deforming stresses thus allowing the bones to develop in their normal shape from an early age. 
•	All taut ligaments at the medial side of the ankle and foot are divided and any tendon that is too tight to allow full correction is lengthened including the calcaneal tendon (tendoAchilles). 
•	Finally the tarsal bones thus released are restored to their normal relationships, particular attention being paid to the talus and navicular bone. 
•	The peroneus brevis is present on the lateral side of the foot and is an evertor; hence it is not released.

questions.text: Bone pain in Paget’s disease is reduced by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bisphosphonates 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol :
•	Paget’s disease, due to abnormal osteoclast function producing disordered bone remodeling and honeycomb like bone architecture is benefited by bisphosphonates (BPNs). 
•	They arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain and improve secondary symptoms.Long-lasting remissions may be induced.
•	Alendronate, risedronate, pamidronate and zoledronate are used now. They are more convenient, more effective and cheaper than calcitonin. 
•	Combined use of BPNs and calcitonin further increases efficacy.
•	Treatment with BPN should not exceed 6 months; but courses may be repeated after a gap.

•	After finishing resorption they are seen in Howship’s Lacunae which are shallow pits or excavations.
•	PTH stimulates Osteoblasts which further send RANK Ligand to stimulate Osteoclasts for Resorption of Bone.

questions.text: A 6-week-old female infant presents with the neck deformity and palpable mass shown in Figure A. She has had persistent lateral tilting of her head to the right since birth, and rotation of the neck is restricted. In this age group, what is the most common cause of this rotational abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Congenital muscular torticollis             
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol :  
•	Congenital muscular torticollis (CMT) is the most common cause of torticollis in infancy. Neurologic disorders and osseous abnormalities, such as Klippel-Feil, are less common.
•	Ultrasonography is considered the modality of choice for differentiating (CMT) from other more serious pathologies in the neck when a palpable mass is present. The initial treatment of of CMT is conservative, and good outcomes can be expected in the majority of these cases. 
•	Tang et al used US to examine affected sternocleidomastoid muscles in patients with CMT classified as having one of four types of fibrosis. 
•	They determined the change in fibrosis type over time and concluded that CMT is a dynamic disease which can be accurately assessed and followed by ultrasonography. 
•	Benign paroxysmal torticollis is a self-limiting condition occurring during infancy. It resolves by the age of two to three years. 
•	Paroxysmal torticollis of infancy is a rare disorder characterized by periodic episodes of torticollis which are associated with pallor, agitation and ataxia. 
•	The etiology is unknown and no treatment is effective, however the condition is usually benign and self-limiting.

questions.text: Which of the following vertebral fractures involves disruption of ligaments of anterior, middle and posterior columns
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chance fracture
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol :  
•	Chance fracture is because of excessive flexion-distraction force and since this involves all the three columns this is an unstable fracture (generally a fracture involving only one column is stable and more than one is unstable)

questions.text: The above encircled radiological finding is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
Looser zones (also known as cortical infractions, Milkman's lines or umbauzonen) ::
Wide transverse lucencies traversing part way through a bone, usually at right angles to the involved cortex and are associated most frequently with osteomalacia and rickets.
They are pseudofractures and considered a type of insufficiency fracture.
Typically, the fractures have sclerotic irregular margins, and are often symmetrical.
Underlying conditions ::
•	Osteomalacia
•	Renal osteodytrophy
•	Fibrous dysplasia
•	Hyperthyroidism
•	Paget's disease of bone
•	X linked hypophosphataemia
•	Osteogenesisimperfecta
Location(s) ::
•	Pubic rami
•	Medial proximal femur
•	Lateral scapula
•	Posterior proximal ulna
•	Ribs
It is named after Emil Looser, Swiss surgeon (1877-1936).

questions.text: Which nerve is most at risk in the injury in the accompanying radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radial nerve
Reference: Read the text below
Sol:     
•	The radiograph demonstrates a transverse fracture of the distal half of the humeral shaft. The radial nerve runs in a groove on the posterior aspect of the humerus as it courses into the forearm compartment and is therefore at high risk of injury. 
•	If the nerve injury is apparent before any manipulation has been done, the fracture should be reduced; the nerve injury should be observed since the nerve function will likely improve with time.
•	If the nerve injury is only present after reduction, immediate surgical exploration is warranted because the nerve might be trapped in the fracture site. At this level of the arm, the ulnar and median nerves are well protected by muscle.
•	The posterior interosseous nerve is a distal branch of the radial nerve and may be injured in fractures near the radial head, but it is in no danger from injuries at the level seen in this radiograph.There is no “ascending circumflex brachial nerve.

choices.text: The first sign is usually loss of pulse in the extremity
Passive flexion of the extremity proximal to the involved compartment will aggravate the pain
Surgical decompression (fasciectomy) is necessary only as a last resort
These syndromes are most commonly associated with supracondylar fractures of the humerus and proximal tibia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding compartment syndromes following orthopedic injuries is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

These syndromes are most commonly associated with supracondylar fractures of the humerus and proximal tibia
Reference: Read the text below
Sol:     
•	Compartment syndromes result from increasing pressures in the fascial compartments of the arm or leg.
•	When the pressure in the muscles is greater than that of the capillaries, ischemia and necrosis of the muscles occur even though the arterial pressure is still high enough to produce pulses; pulselessness is an unreliable sign.
•	Extreme pain (out of proportion to the injury), pain on passive extension of the fingers or toes, pallor of the extremity, motor paralysis, and paresthesias are all components of the syndrome.
•	The patient will usually hold the injured part in a position of flexion to maximally relax the fascia and reduce the pain; passive extension will usually produce severe pain.
•	The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring intracompartmental pressures, but whenever physical findings or symptoms are suspicious, immediate surgical decompression by fasciectomy is indicated since delay is likely to lead to irreversible damage.

questions.text: Wilson fracture is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Volar plate fracture
Ref.:Read the text below
Sol :
•	Volar plate fractures are the result of hyperextension. This injury typically involve the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers.
•	At this location, the volar plate (a dense fibrous band) forms a portion of the capsule. Typically, there is a small fragment of bone avulsed from the volar aspect of the base of the proximal phalanx. 
•	If not repaired, this can lead to instability. 
•	A Wilson fracture refers to a volar plate injury to the middle phalanx of a finger.

choices.text: Soft tissues overlying the fracture or surgical approach that are poor in quality due to burns

questions.text: Contraindications to open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Old myocardial infarction
Ref.:Read the text below
Sol :
Contraindications to surgical reconstruction (open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) are as follows : 
•	Active infection (local or systemic) or osteomyelitis 
•	Cases in which amputation would better serve the limb and the patient. 
•	Medical conditions that contraindicate surgery of anesthesia (eg, recent myocardial infarction) 
•	Osteoporotic bone that is too weak to sustain internal or external fixation. 
•	Soft tissues overlying the fracture or surgical approach that are poor in quality due to burns, surgical scars, or infection (In such scenarios, soft tissue coverage is recommended.)

•	Intra articular Fracture of Calcaneum : Lover’s Fracture
•	Fracture subluxation of lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption : Undertaker’s Fracture

questions.text: In rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Periosteal reaction
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
Neuropathies in RA 
•	Vasculitis → motor and sensory peripheral neuropathy or due to entrapment or compression
•	Affects median- wrist (carpal tunnel), ulnar- elbow, radial as the posterior interosseous nerve
•	Tendon Rupture: (Etiology) in RA 
•	Proteolytic enzymes from the hypertrophic synovitis
•	Direct synovial invasion of the tendon
•	Intratendinous nodules (may prevent free gliding of a tendon) 
•	Attrition where the tendon is abraded running over sharp bony prominences 
•	Extensor tendon rupture is more common than flexor and ulnar tendons before radial tendons

choices.text: Lateral Patellar Plica is the most common symptomatic plica
It commonly presents as Anterior Knee Pain
It can be associated with Chondromalacia Patellae
Plicae ≥ 1 mm may be present in over 70% of individuals

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Plica Syndrome of Knee ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Synovial plicae are folds of synovium, thought to represent embryologic remnants.
•	They have been implicated in anterior knee pain and possibly in chondromalacia patellae although their role remains controversial
•	- Medial patellar plica: most common symptomatic plica 
- suprapatellar plica / superior patellar plica
- infrapatellar plica / ligamentum mucosum
- lateral patellar plica: rare (<1%)
•	They range in shape from a ridge or shelf to more discrete cord-like structure
•	Medial patellar plica syndrome is one of the conditions that can be associated with the presence of synovial plicae of the knee (in this instance a medial plica). It can be a common source of anterior knee pain.
•	Patients may present with pain over the anteromedial aspect of the knees (mostly above the joint line ) and this may be accompanied by episodes of crepitation, catching, and pseudo-locking sensations.
•	Plicae ≥ 1 mm may be present in over 70% of individuals and are mostly asymptomatic . Under certain circumstances, they carry the potential to become inflamed and symptomatic. There can be fibrosis of a plica rendering it inflexible.

questions.text: A 2-month old baby is lifted by her mother by holding the wrist of the child. The child started crying and was not moving her elbow. The most likely diagnosis is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulled elbow
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
PULLED ELBOW – 
•	This condition occurs in children between 2 – 5 years of age. 
•	The head of the radius is pulled partly out of the annular ligament when a child is lifted by the wrist. 
•	The child starts crying and is unable to move the affected limb. 
•	The forearm lies in an attitude of pronation. 
•	There may be mild swelling at the elbow. 
•	It is not possible to see the subluxated head on an X-ray because it is still cartilaginous. 
•	X-rays are only taken to rule out any other bony injury. 

TREATMENT – 
•	The head is reduced by fully supinating the forearm and applying direct pressure over the head of the radius. 
•	A sudden click is heard or felt as the head goes back into its place. 
•	The child becomes comfortable and starts moving his elbow almost immediately.

questions.text: An eight-year-old child sustained fracture through upper third of humerus after a trivial fall. An X-ray shows lytic lesion in the bone at the fracture site. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Unicameral bone cyst
Ref: Read the text below 
Sol:
•	A unicameral bone cyst, otherwise known as a simple bone cyst, is a fluid-filled cavity in the bone, lined by compressed fibrous tissue. It usually occurs in the long bones of a growing child, especially the upper part of the humerus (50 - 60% of the time) or the upper part of the femur (25-30 % of the time). Other bones, however, can be affected.
•	These cysts usually affect children primarily between the ages of 5 to 15, but can affect older children or adults. In older children and adults, they tend to occur in flat bones (such as the pelvis, jaw, skull or rib cage) or in the large heel bone (calcaneus)
•	Unicameral bone cysts are considered benign. They do not metastasize (spread) beyond the bone. Some heal spontaneously, while others enlarge. More invasive cysts can grow to fill most of the bone's metaphysis (the transitional zone where the shaft of the bone joins the end of the bone) and cause what is known as a pathological fracture. A more invasive cyst could also destroy the bone's growth plate, leading to shortening of the bone. Shortening in the upper arm (humerus) usually does not cause a functional problem, but it may produce a cosmetic problem if it occurs in early childhood.

questions.text: What happens to angle A and B in fracture calcaneum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A decreases,B increases
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
A is Bohler’sangle.B is Crucial angle of Gissane

questions.text: Patient is presenting with pain around base of thumb (De Querverian’s Tenosynovitis). What are marked in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: All the following are used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adson test
Ref.: Maheshwari-Pg 57
Sol : 
•	Tinel’s Sign : Tinel’s test is performed by tapping the median nerve along the course in the wrist. A positive test is found when this causes worsening of the tingling when the nerve is tapped – positive in carpal tunnel syndrome. 
•	Phalen’s Sign : Phalen’s test is done by pushing the back of your hands together for one minute. This compresses the carpal tunnel and is also positive when it causes the same symptoms you have been experiencing with your carpal tunnel syndrome. 
•	Electrodiagnostic test : Definitive analysis of nerve function can be performed with a device called an EMG (electromyography) which, can detect abnormalities in nerve impulse conduction; these nerve conduction abnormalities are the cause of carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms. 
•	The EMC does not always need to be performed, but may be done if a patient’s symptoms are not typical of carpal tunnel syndrome. 
•	Adson's test is used to assess for the presence of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome at the scalene triangle.

questions.text: The given splint is used in the management of ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Developmental dysplasia of Hip
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
•	The image shows Von Rosen splint used in the management of Development Dysplasia of Hip

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Colle’s fracture –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Volar tilt
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
COLLES’ FRACTURE – 
•	This is a fracture at the distal end of the radius, at its cortico-cancellous junction (about 2 cm from the distal articular surface), in adults, with typical displacement. 
•	It is the commonest fracture in people above 40 years of age, and is particularly common in women because of post-menopausal osteoporosis. 
•	It nearly always results from a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
PATHOANATOMY – 
•	The fracture line runs transversely at the cortico-cancellous junction. 
•	In the majority of cases, one or more of the following displacements occur – 
•	Impaction of fragments
•	Dorsal displacement
•	Dorsal tilt
•	Lateral (Radial) displacement
•	Lateral (Radial) tilt
•	Supination. 
•	As the displacement occurs, some amount of communition of the dorsal and lateral cortices, and that of the soft cancellous bone of the distal fragment occurs. 
•	Some of the injuries commonly associated with Colles’ fracture are – 
•	Fracture of the styloid process of the ulna
•	Rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament
•	Rupture of the triangular cartilage of the ulna
•	Rupture of the inter-osseous radio-ulnar ligament, causing radio-ulnar subluxation. 
DIAGNOSIS – 
•	The patient presents with pain, swelling and deformity of the wrist. 
•	On examination, tenderness and irregularity of the lower end of the radius is found. 
•	There may be a typical ‘dinner fork deformity’. 
•	The radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level or at a little higher than the ulnar styloid process. 
RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES – 
•	The dorsal tilt is the most characteristic displacement. 
•	It can be detected by looking at the direction of the distal articular surface of the radius on a lateral X-ray. 
•	Normally it faces ventrally. 
•	Similarly, a lateral tilt can be detected on an antero-posterior X-ray. 
•	Normally, the distal articular surface faces medially. 
TREATMENT – 
•	Treatment of Colles’ fracture is essentially conservative. 
•	For an undisplaced fracture, immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks is sufficient. 
•	For displaced fractures, the standard method of treatment is manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in a Colles’ cast. 
COMPLICATIONS – 
•	Stiffness of joints
•	Malunion – Persistence of dinner fork deformity
•	Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
•	Carpal tunnel syndrome
•	Sudeck’s osteodystrophy
•	Rupture of the extensor pollicis  longus tendon

Supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.text: Commonly performed procedure of triple arthrodesis of foot includes fusion of the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Talocalcaneal, talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints
Ref.: Essential Orthopedics, Maheswari- 197
Sol : 
•	Triple arthrodesis is performed after the age of 12 years because before this the ones are cartilaginous and it is difficult to achieve fusion. It is done for surgical correction of clubfoot/CTEV. 
•	Triple arthrodesis consists of fusion of three joints of the foot : 
•	Subtalar (talocalcanea) 
•	Calcaneocuboid 
•	Talonavicular (most difficult to achieve).

choices.text: Release of peroneus brevis from its insertion

questions.text: Steps in the operative correction of congenital talipes equinovarus include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Release of peroneus brevis from its insertion
Ref.: John Crawford Adam,s - 373-375
Sol : 
•	The crucial component in CTEV is subluxation of the talonavicular joint. The soft tissues on the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped and shorter than normal. 
•	Aim of treatment is to set the tarsal bones in normal relationship to one another and to relieve deforming stresses thus allowing the bones to develop in their normal shape from an early age. 
•	All taut ligaments at the medial side of the ankle and foot are divided and any tendon that is too tight to allow full correction is lengthened including the calcaneal tendon (tendoAchilles). 
•	Finally the tarsal bones thus released are restored to their normal relationships, particular attention being paid to the talus and navicular bone. 
•	The peroneus brevis is present on the lateral side of the foot and is an evertor; hence it is not released.

choices.text: Ultrasound guided aspiration and intravenous antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Emergency aspiration and washout of the hip joint followed by intravenous antibiotics  
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:     
•	Emergency intervention is needed to treat the compartment syndrome of hip secondary to post septic arthritis of hip but at the same time it is important to differentiate it from septic arthritis  and transient synovitis and for that blood counts and USG are the key vital points.

questions.text: Identify the semicircular line shown in figure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shenton’s line
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
•	Shenton’s line is an imaginary line joining the medial cortex of femoral neck to the lower border of superior pubic ramus.
•	It is breeched in fracture neck of femur,head of femur,superior pubic rami and dislocation of hip.

choices.text: Genetic deficiency of carbonic anhydrase II

questions.text: A man aged 80 years presents with slowly progressive enlargement of his head circumference, deformities of long bones and spine, and chronic pain of the affected skeletal segments.Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and high urine hydroxyproline.X-ray findings are consistent with Paget disease.Which among the following is the most Probable pathogenetic mechanism of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Paramyxovirus infection of osteoclasts
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
•	Paget disease, also termed as osteitis deformans,is fequently  affecting the bone condition of middle-aged to elderly peoples.
•	Polyostotic, affects the axial skeleton, spine, pelvis, proximal femur, and head. Usually,it seems to be gradual enlargement of the head and chronic bone pain.
•	Disorder of osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity affecting the bone coarse and congeal.
•	Paget himself proposed a viral hypothesis for the pathogenesis of this condition, but only recent molecular and immunologic techniques permits the identification of paramyxoviruses (measles and respiratory syncytial virus) in osteoclasts of affected bones.
•	In many cases, the diagnosis is done by radiologic investigations. General reduction in bone mass is defining the indication of osteoporosis. Its most common form, the condition affects elderly peoples especially women after menopause.
•	Characteristically causes pathologic fractures of the femoral neck or compression fractures of vertebral bones.
•	osteopetrosis is known to be genetic deficiency of carbonic anhydrase II is one cause of the rare hereditary disorders collectively which is due to osteoclast dysfunction.
•	This condition manifests in infants or childhood with bone fragility and recurrent fractures. The bone becomes stony hard consistency and is brittle.
•	Multiple myeloma causes due to monoclonal proliferation of underlying plasma cells the most frequent primary bone neoplasm. It results in multifocal inflation of neoplastic plasma cells in bones, manifesting with punch-out osteolytic lesions on x-ray films.
•	Vertebrae, skull, pelvic and ribs bones are very frequently affected.

questions.text: An elderly female is on treatment for osteoporosis with alendronate for 7 years. She now presents with complaints of hip pain. The best investigation for her would be –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

X-ray
Ref: The American Journal of Geriatric Pharmacotherapy, Volume 9pg 194–198.
Sol: 
In the above case scenario patient is having pain & she is on alendronate since last 7 years, which is highly suggestive of fragility fracture due to prolonged use of Bisphosphonates. X-ray would be best investigation to see fractures.

•    Despite the great success achieved by using bisphosphonets in osteoporotic patients during the last two decades, there remains a group of patients who may develop femoral fragility fractures secondary to Severely suppressed Bone Turnover (SSBT) caused by prolonged bisphosphonate use, mainly with alendronate. 
•    The number of these cases is still relatively small but will probably increase in the future owing to the large number of patients treated with these drugs. 
•    It is therefore important to reserve continuation of bisphosphonates therapy for more than five years for selected cases.
•    Furthermore, clinicians should be aware of the association between long-term bisphosphonates therapy and femoral fragility fractures. 
•    In patients with early changes, such as prodromal hip/thigh pain and lateral cortical thickness, stopping bisphosphonate therapy and prophylactic nailing should be considered. 
•    In patients with femoral fragility fractures, healing disturbances are not uncommon, and should be anticipated and treated accordingly. 
•    If continuation of antiresorptive therapy is indicated despite the occurrence of femoral fragility fractures, teriparatide represents a promising alternative to bisphosphonates because it reduces microdamage accumulation caused by Severely suppressed Bone Turnover (SSBT).
Figure. Radiographs of the (A) right and (B) left hips of a patient who presented with bilateral, sequential bisphosphonate-related subtrochanteric fractures. The transverse fracture pattern on the lateral half of the femoral cortex both in the right and left hips raises the suspicion of a possible preexisting linear crack involving the lateral half of the femoral cortex, which gave way and progressed into an oblique fracture on the medial cortex. There is also significant cortical hypertrophy of the femoral shaft, bilaterally below the fracture.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

De Quervain’s tenovaginitis

The image shows Finkelstein test used for diagnosing De QuervainsTenovaginitis.The condition results from the inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicislongus and extensor pollicisbrevistendons.The pain is aggrevated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation.

questions.text: All of the following are possible surgical interventions in tuberculosis of the spine except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Laminectomy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol :   
•	In the usual anterior paradiscal type of TB spine the compression of the cord takes place primarily and maximally anteriorly. 
•	Therefore it is rational to adequately decompress the cord anteriorly by anterior or anterolateral approach. 
•	Laminectomy for decompression is contraindicated as this procedure is inadequate for decompression for the anterior part of the cord besides it removes the healthy areas of the vertebrae thus rendering the vertebral column unstable and liable for pathological dislocation.

choices.text: Subluxation of inferior radio ulnar joint
Tendon rupture most commonly extensor carpii radialis longus

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a complication of Colles’ fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tendon rupture most commonly extensor carpii radialis longus
Ref: Read the text below
Sol :   
•	Tendon rupture most commonly extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is a rare complication and occurs a long time after the fracture has united. 
•	Treatment is by the transfer of Extensor Indicis to the EPL as the frayed tendon edges are not amenable to repair.

questions.text: Disk herniations most commonly occur at the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels 
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol : 
•	The L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels are the sites of 95 percent of disk herniations. 
•	The majority of all clinically significant disk herniations producing lower extremity radiculopathy occur at these levels. 
•	Although not very specific, the straight leg raise test is a sensitive indicator for disk herniations at these levels.

questions.text: Three bony prominence (triangle) of elbow is not altered in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Supracondylar fracture humerus
Ref.: Essential Orthopedics, Maheswari- 79
Sol : 
•	The three bony points around the elbow, i.e. the medial epicondyle, the lateral epicondyle and tip of the olecranon are important landmarks in diagnosis of injuries around the elbow. 
•	Normally in an elbow flexed to 90 degrees, the three bony points form a near isosceles triangle, but they lie in a horizontal line in an extended elbow. 
•	The base of the triangle (between the two epicondyles) is the longest arm. The side between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon tip is the shortest. The head of the radius, also considered the ‘4th bony point’ can be palpated in a semiflexed elbow just distal to the lateral epicondyle. 
•	Three bony prominence (triangle) of elbow is not altered in supracondylar fracture humerus

choices.text: Edema of muscles due to injury
Fracture of hematoma within the compartment
Edema of muscles due to ischemia

questions.text: A compartment syndrome in a leg can result from all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Compound fracture
Ref.: Essential Orthopedics, Maheswari, - 38, 1
Sol : 
•    The limbs contain muscles in compartments enclosed by bones, fascia and interosseous membrance. 
•    A rise in pressure within these compartments due to any reason may jeopardize the blood supply to the muscles and nerves within the compartment – “compartment syndrome”.

choices.text: For analyzing the pain due to orthopaedic malignancies

questions.text: Mirel's criteria is used for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: The tensile strength of a bone is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

The tensile strength of bone is due to stress oriented collagen fibres which make up the organic component of the intercellular matrix of bone.

questions.text: Most metabolically active part in bone is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Bone formation is more than bone resorption on the periosteal surface and bone resorption is more than bone formation on the endosteal surface, and it is metabolically most active part of bone.

questions.text: Initial stage of clinical union of bone is equivalent to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

At the stage of consolidation, Woven bone formation occurs and it restricts movements in all planes as it is hard and strong, thus also known as hard callus. Haematoma formation and callus are the initial stage of fracture healing.

choices.text: Serum vitamin D levels are normal

questions.text: A 2- year old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Resolution of skeletal deformities occurs completely with treatment with vitamin D and calcium. If the deformity persists even after radiological healing (the best way to predict healing) in rickets, surgery (i.e. corrective osteotomy) to correct that deformity can be done. However, surgery should be done only after the levels of ALP are brought to normal as when ALP is raised, bone is soft and not in a state to hold the fixation implant.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presented with progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and osteomyelitis of jaw with pathological fracture. X-Ray shows chalky white deposits in bone. Probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Pancytopenia due to obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth (abnormal bleeding, anemia, infections and failure to thrive). Due to pancytope- nia, there is extramedullary haematopoiesis (hepa- tospleenomegaly). Bone pain and pathological frac- tures(fragile brittle bone) are common.
